summary.text_en: Galen was greatest physician of ancient Rome! He studied human anatomy through animal dissection, discovering arteries carry blood not air. His medical works dominated Western medicine for 1400 years. Though some theories later proven wrong, he laid foundation of anatomy and physiology.

story.text_en: In 157 AD, Galen became physician to gladiators. He treated gladiator wounds, observing organs and bones, accumulating vast anatomical knowledge. Later became physician to Emperor Marcus Aurelius. Since Rome forbade human dissection, he dissected pigs, monkeys, dogs. He discovered cutting arteries causes bleeding, proving arteries contain blood not air! He wrote over 500 medical works, becoming medieval medicine authority.

fun_facts.text_en: As gladiator physician, he reduced mortality from 60% to 5%, gaining great fame!
He mainly dissected monkeys as most human-like. But this led to errors, like believing human liver has 5 lobes.
He wrote over 500 works, about 3 million words, equivalent to 30 thick books today!
He was physician to 5 Roman emperors, extremely high status.

experiment.title_en: Classic Experiment: Proving Arteries Contain Blood
experiment.description_en: Before Galen, people believed arteries carried 'pneuma' (air), only veins had blood. Galen did simple experiment: he cut artery in live pig, bright red blood gushed out! He also tied artery at both ends, middle section bulged, proving filled with fluid. This experiment completely overturned 'arteries contain air' false theory, early paradigm of experimental medicine.
experiment.why_en: Artery walls thick and elastic, can withstand high-pressure blood pumped by heart. Arterial blood high oxygen content, bright red color.

simple_explanation.text_en: Galen like curious detective, wanting to know how body works inside. But couldn't dissect humans then, so he dissected pigs, monkeys to study. He discovered: arteries carry blood not air! Brain is commander, not heart. He also discovered many organ functions. Though some ideas wrong (like blood doesn't circulate), he taught people to learn medicine through experiments, not guessing.

impact.text_en: Galen was most influential ancient physician after Hippocrates. His works preserved through Arab physicians, dominated European medicine 1400 years until Renaissance when Vesalius discovered his errors through human dissection. Though some Galenic theories wrong (like blood doesn't circulate, liver has 5 lobes), his emphasis on experimental observation and systematic dissection methodology crucial for medical development. He pioneered experimental medicine.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Humoral theory and clinical observation methods

influenced.contribution_en: Arab medicine inherited and developed Galenic system
Corrected Galen's errors through human dissection
Discovered blood circulation, overturning Galenic theory
Modern anatomy inherited Galen's experimental methods

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Galen inherited Hippocratic humoral theory, Aristotelian biological methods, and Alexandrian dissection tradition. Arab physicians like Avicenna preserved and developed his works. During Renaissance, Vesalius discovered many Galenic errors through human dissection (since Galen mainly dissected animals). Harvey discovered blood circulation, completely overturning Galenic blood theory. But Galen's methodology emphasizing experiment and dissection inherited by modern medicine.

quiz.question_en: What important discovery did Galen prove through experiments?
quiz.explanation_en: One of Galen's most important experimental discoveries was proving arteries carry blood not air. Before him, people believed arteries contained 'pneuma' (spirit/air). Galen by cutting arteries in live animals, observed bright red blood gushing out, thus overturning this false theory. This discovery demonstrated importance of experimental methods in medicine, early paradigm of experimental medicine.
